"Until dawn" is a Horror movie based on the popular game under the same name, but let me tell you the movie and game are two very different things. If you are going into this movie thinking you are getting a sequel to a popular choose your own path horror game you are wrong. This Flim is more of a prequel than a squeal to the game, with totally different characters and a different story line that only ties a bit into the game, also the Flim takes place before the main events of the game. Now I personally enjoyed the movie, mostly because I didn't play the game before I saw the movie. But after playing the game my mind has changed about the Flim. Sure it's a good, fun, and one gory hell of a ride but it's more of a you'll watch once and most likely never again. So that is why I have given this the rating of 3/5 Stars.

Didn’t even get through all of it before I left. A horror movie shouldn’t be dependent on expected jump scares, and I feel this is what it turned out to be.

"Survive the night or become part of it" is the name of the game in one of the latest horror installments, "Until Dawn." Derived from the 2015 PlayStation release, tis a playful, bloody story of a group of friends thrust into a world of perpetual nightmare and death, including by way of a pickaxe wielding villain. They say a cat has nine (9) lives. This film has apparently seen those nine (9) lives and raised the related humans four (4) more, allowing for any glimmer of hope and escape. Amongst the personal vibes of Evil Dead 2 in part, Ella Rubin crushes the role of "Clover," displaying Ash-type strength and stamina throughout the many long nights. Until Dawn doesn't materially move the needle, but it scratches the itch, and goddammit, that's good enough for me today.

Okay, so I went into Until Dawn blind, not having played the game, and honestly, it was a bit of a letdown. The setup’s intriguing: a group of friends, led by Clover (Ella Rubin), get stuck in this creepy, rainy valley where they keep dying in brutal ways—slashed by a masked killer, mauled by some clown-thing—and wake up to relive the night. Cool concept, but it gets repetitive fast. The scares are loud and gory, which is fun for a bit, but they feel like the same trick over and over. Ella Rubin’s decent as Clover, hunting for her missing sister, and Peter Stormare’s Dr. Hill is unsettling in a good way, but the other characters are forgettable—just there to scream and die. The story tries to tug at your heart with Clover’s grief, but it’s too rushed to care. The big finale, where they break the time-loop with a sacrifice and some mystical mumbo-jumbo, felt like every other horror movie ending. It looks slick, and the blood’s aplenty if you like that, but it’s shallow and predictable. I wanted more twists or depth, but it’s just an okay horror flick that fizzles out.

The original game of Until Dawn was a campy homage to the genre of horror films that so many reviews are criticizing the movie for actually being. Very LAME video game-movie: Clover and her teenaged friends are trapped on a mysterious island where a masked stranger stalks them all and kills them, just to have the ritual repeat itself the next day ...a la Groundhog Day. This tired, formula-thriller is a very obvious rehash of Friday the 13th and shows like From which also explores recurring death motifs. Some tell-tale signs this is a bad movie? Not that bad a movie. but it ends up tripping and falling in the end. Another movie where most of the plot is given away in the trailer.   Our young people find themselves in a house where various scary folks chase and kill them.  Upon their death, our gang finds themselves 'reset' to the start of the night. They go through around 3 nights of getting killed in creative ways before they decide to start investigating and trying to figure out what is going on.   This is where the movie starts to get a little interesting.   They investigate their surroundings, find some clues and start to discover the environment they are in and why some things are going on. Just when you think 'scoopy and the gang' will figure out what is going on, the plot just gives up.  they reset and can't seem to figure out which loop they are in, and we find out somehow we jumped from an interesting 4th loop to their 13th 'last loop', with some of the scary scenes on the trailers are just video clips they find on their phones (I guess their phones to not reset?) Worried they won't reset in this last loop, they finally make a bold move and try to do more to get out of their situation (avoiding spoilers).   When we find out the why, it's a big let-down, and doesn't explain any of the supernatural things going on (nor why they reset after death).   But they do leave off hinting at a sequel - which, given, this movie, probably won't be happening. Probably best left for Cable/Streaming.

So, video game adaptations have actually been doing pretty damn well lately. The Super Mario Bros. Movie — fun! Fallout — awesome! The Last of Us — emotional gut punch! Gran Turismo — way better than it had any right to be! We were starting to think, 'Hey! Maybe the video game movie curse is dead!” But no. Until Dawn is here to slap us back to reality. Hard.. Now, I'll be fair for a second — adapting Until Dawn was always gonna be tricky. The game is basically a glorified 'choose-your-own-adventure' story. You have QuickTime events, you make choices, characters live or die... it's built on replayability. So trying to turn THAT into a 2-hour movie was always going to be like building a house out of Jenga blocks And I’ll give them this: they tried to get creative. They didn’t just do a straight retelling. They attempted something different. But here’s the thing — we don’t grade movies on effort. We’re not giving out participation trophies. Either it works, or it doesn't — and this one just... doesn't As an adaptation? Hardcore Until Dawn fans are gonna be pissed. It strays way too far from the game’s spirit. Characters get reworked, plotlines get Frankensteined together, and the big twist that made the game so memorable? Yeah, they botched that too But maybe you’re thinking, 'Okay, I never played the game. Maybe I'll just watch it as a regular horror movie!' Bad news, my friend. Even if you haven't played the game, Until Dawn feels like a cheap mashup of Edge of Tomorrow and Groundhog Day, but without any of the brains, heart, or creativity those movies had.. Die, reset, die, reset! Seen it. Done better. And the real kicker? As a horror movie — which is what it should nail — it’s even worse We are living through a second golden age of horror right now. Hereditary, Get Out, The Babadook, Talk to Me, The Invisible Man — horror movies are smart, stylish, and genuinely unsettling these days. Until Dawn feels like it crawled out of 2005 and not in a cool, nostalgic way. It’s not scary. It’s just a non-stop parade of cheap-ass jump scares. LAAAH — cat jumps out of closet! BLAAAH — mirror fake-out! BLAAAH — hand on shoulder that's just a friend Honestly, they could have just renamed this movie Jump Scare: The Movie and at least been honest about it. There’s no tension. No atmosphere. No lingering dread. Just loud noises and quick cuts. So in the end, Until Dawn is a mess. It fails as an adaptation. It fails as a movie. It fails as horror. It’s a triple threat… just for all the wrong reasons. Save yourself the time. Play the original game. Hell, watch someone else play the game on YouTube. You'll get a better story, better characters, and honestly, way better scares. This movie's a hard skip.

If you came to watch this movie because you’re a fan of the game don’t have high expectations probably the only thing close to the game is the title and they do not take anything from the source material. Although I do like the concept that they came up with instead. The premise of this film is that a group of friends go to this house but they get stuck in this time loop where they have to survive “Until Dawn”. But the catch is that there is a supernatural entity that hunts them down sometimes it will be a zombie and sometimes it will be a demon. I do like the first act of this movie but the second act seemed very rushed so after one of the characters die she wakes up and they tell her that she’s has been out for a multitude of days . To me this just seemed a little rushed they could have done a plethora of different ideas but they decided to rush it. Ultimately if your a fan of the game I do not recommend but if your a person who hasn’t played the game it will be more likely interesting as a concept although the second act felt really rushed in some scenes the first act I really enjoyed.

I went to go see the film with my sister 5 days ago, we were hoping if my cousin could come along with us, but she couldn't. My sister asked before watching the film and since I have played the original game three months ago, she asked what the game was about, the plot was about 8 friends returning to the lodge a year later after the disappearance of twin sisters. Then, a killer came with an revenge plot to attack the friends when he held them as responsibles and getting the twins killed. Because the game shared similarities through films, like Saw and I Know What You Did Last Summer. I went to see the movie and my sister called the film "dull", because the live action movie had similarities with Happy Death Day, because the film introduced five friends, completely different from the game. We had fun with the jumpscares, but I wasn't satisfied with the runtime, taking 3 friends away and not honoring what made the original game special. When we left the movie, we rated 8 out of 10 stars, some fans have a point. The film wasn't good, but it wasn't bad either. It was just regular. Let's be real, Melanie was similar than Beth or Hannah. Clover shared similarities than Josh. Nina was similar than Jessica. Abe was similar than Mike. Max was similar than Matt. Megan was similar than Emily. No Chris. Neither Ashley. Not Sam. Some behaved like the characters from the game, but in different choices, except when meeting their fates. We felt that the director, David F. Sandberg, should've done more than that. Better directing. Better screenwriters. And what they shouldn't do was to cut nights, because leaving with five nights will make the fans disappointed some ways, it's making reference than Five Nights at Freddy's movie. If they had done that, the fans would've been satisfied and happy with the results, versus the one we've seen. The one that surprised us in some ways it wasn't supposed to disappoint us. There were PlayStation games that turned into live action. Uncharted. Borderlands. The Last Of Us. Resident Evil. Until Dawn. Two and a half disappointed the lore fans.

A Gruesome Groundhog Day with Teeth. David F. Sandberg's Until Dawn arrives with a wicked grin, initially luring you in with the familiar tropes of a secluded setting and a group of young adults stumbling into potential danger. The opening of the film gives off Cabin in the Woods vibe, introducing a cast of characters – Clover, her ex Max, friends Nina and Megan, and Nina's boyfriend Abe – as they embark on a search for Clover's missing sister, Melanie. The film pivots when the group finds themselves trapped in a time loop within a seemingly innocuous visitor center. This is where Until Dawn embraces its gaming inspiration, echoing the "live-die-live again" formula popularized by titles like Happy Death Day. The recurring nights, marked by a chilling hourglass, the mystery of the masked pickaxe assailant and the discovery of a hidden house deliver genuine scares and intrigue. However, as the nights bleed into one another, Until Dawn unfortunately begins to lose its way. While the time loop mechanic provides ample opportunities for creative and gruesome deaths, the film frustratingly neglects to fully explore the initial driving force: Melanie's disappearance. The urgency of finding her gets somewhat lost in the story telling. Until Dawn offers a thrilling, albeit slightly uneven, ride. It successfully captures the spirit of making crucial decisions with life-or-death consequences, reminiscent of its gaming namesake (which may be ahead of its time, or just fly over peoples heads). The film stumbles by sidelining its initial premise, the relentless cycle of terror and the inventive ways the characters meet their demise makes the film a fun popcorn flick to check out.

Until Dawn offers a promising start, delivering chaotic horror energy, creative deaths, and a genuinely entertaining first half that feels fresh and fun. Unfortunately, the movie loses momentum quickly. The second half relies heavily on exposition, skips over key story developments, and fumbles its emotional payoff. While the first act shows real potential, the rushed conclusion and clumsy lore connections ultimately leave the experience feeling incomplete. Fans of the game may find it frustrating, but casual viewers might still enjoy the initial thrills.

The 2025 horror film "Until Dawn" hits theaters without any major star power, but it delivers a well-crafted cinematic experience inspired by a video game. Going into the movie, I was completely unfamiliar with the game's narrative, which left me focused solely on the film's storyline. There were moments where I felt like a deeper understanding of the video game would have enhanced my grasp of the movie, ultimately detracting from the viewing experience. It seemed like I needed to play the game to fully appreciate the film, which was a significant drawback. That said, the film wasn't all bad. It had its confusing moments, with a sense of disorientation until the plot began to come together. The pacing felt off, as it took far too long to reveal the necessary details for understanding the story. I found myself perplexed by the main character, the mysterious man in the house—his motivations and purpose for gathering the group were unclear, which left me feeling like I missed out due to my lack of familiarity with the game. In conclusion, I believe the filmmakers have their work cut out for them in building this world. While the film may not be a box office hit, I think it will find its audience on streaming platforms, helping to cultivate the video game franchise's transition to film. It was enjoyable overall, despite the confusion stemming from my unfamiliarity with the game's storyline.

Brad’s view ‘Until Dawn’ is a bit of a mess, relying heavily on overly cranked audio for its numerous jump scares to try and force the audience to be frightened. The most frightening thing about the film is the large number of changes that happened to the story from the original game, with the director throwing in ‘Groundhog Day’, ‘Cabin in the Woods’, and many other throwbacks to other horror games and genres. It loses a lot of the lore (it’s partially there, but really insignificant to the story) and the emotional impact of the game's story. While it does a good job with the deaths and practical effects, the best scares are found in very short snippets towards the end of the film in yet another method of horror storytelling. Josh’s view If you can disconnect from it not being a straight adaptation, you can get a solid fun horror experience out of it that still gives you a decent amount of the game, but still feels that what they might be setting up for a sequel would have been better served for this first film. ‘Until Dawn’ can only be a recommendation if you are into jump scares and gore, or you can fully disconnect yourself from the game. Past that, there may not be a lot worth talking about. Brad: 4.5 Josh: 6.5 Final: 5.5

I had a hell of a time with it!! 👿🥶⏳️ Until Dawn (2025) ⌛️🌚🌃 Until Dawn is such a well made, scary and unexpected horror movie! David F. Sandberg once again! You horror master! It comes at you out of a sudden! It comes at you hard! You aren't really expecting anything and it happens! Creative deaths at it's peak! Now this movie won't stick in your head as years go on primarily bcz it lacks depth overall. It also doesn't feel like a big enough world of whatever is going on. Unlike movies like Annabelle: Creation, Insidious, The Conjuring and more of such, it doesn't have an overall unlimited, infinite possibilities vibe to it like The Further or The Conjuring Universe. It feels pretty much done and dusted. It nowhere affects the quality of the movie but it's just one of the downsides I wanted to highlight. I thought the characters were good! Their acting was good too! The story, what more is needed?? It's a good enough storyline for what the movie intends to do. 💯 I had a Sunday midnight horror experience! Now.. The only truth that the critics spoke was that the second half was bad. In fact, that's a partial lie too! The 2nd half was good! Weaker than the first half but good! It's always the best to watch a movie for yourself! Most of the negatives or downsides pointed out by the critics, were just a hogwash. Overall a scary and creepy movie! Some claim, no one screamed or reacted during the movie. Well, you should come out of social media and know how a person reacts after being scared. If you are lucky, you'll find someone who let's out a sound. It's a quick reaction and if it's a minor or normal one, you cannot hear it due to the loudness of the speakers. The movie was really good! David F. Sandberg knows exactly when to shock and when to let it build to avoid being cliche. Needs talent and practice. Today, in the 2020s no one can do it except for some directors like James Wan and Mike Flanagan. Lastly! Everyone should just go out there and watch this horror epic in the cinemas where the horror is meant to be witnessed! A 7/10 for me! Horror at it's peak! 🤩🥶🥵👀🌃🖤

As a viewer of the film adaptation of Until Dawn, I offer my perspective on the experience, having not played the video game. Upon learning that David F. Sandberg was returning to the horror genre, I harbored some excitement. However, I must express my profound disappointment with the film. While the premise seems promising and fresh, the acting was not up to par and immature. The horror elements were not effectively conveyed through the screen. The actors demonstrated a lack of seriousness in their conversation, ignoring the impact of their previous experiences on their conscience. The movie was not suspenseful due to its visual presentation. By timing the scenes correctly and using slightly darker and more grainy lighting, the story could have the potential to be highly frightening. Although certain aspects of the movie were enjoyable, I did not emerge from the viewing experience with a fully satisfying impression. Fortunately, the film opted for practical effects over CGI, which resulted in some gratifyingly violent moments. However, the off-screen nature of some of the kills diminished the impact of these scenes. David possessed the necessary skills and experience to create a memorable horror film, but instead, he resorted to conventional tropes from numerous horror movies. The film lacked atmosphere, evoking neither sympathy for the characters nor a sense of dread during the viewing. While I do not harbor any animosity towards the film, I believe it was a squandered opportunity.

I was surprised to believe that this movie wasn't gonna be a masterpiece ever since I'd seen the trailer of this a few months ago. I'd only found it interesting. I was actually surprised that this film was gonna be split between both critics and audiences. Honestly, I think that's fair. I went in with as low as I kept my expectations, and I knew that this wasn't gonna be a great horror movie. Actually, this is more or less a bad film but I had fun with it. I had fun with how this film is structured while dealing with the problems that it has. First of all, getting the positives out of the way, I love the carnage candy in this. Pretty bloody, too. I love how you see different ways for these five kids getting kicked off every night from a masked killer, a wendigo, a witch, this kind of water that makes you explode, and even ghost possessions. I love the practical effects being used in this, even by the designs of the wendigo as a whole. I love the concept of dying and coming back to life as they start a new life in the night until you survive until dawn. Yeah, I know, bad pun. I'd even have to admit the exploration of the area they are in is interesting. I'd tell you that, but that would mean I would be spoiling. Unfortunately, that's all the positives that I'd have to share. I think the acting is okay from the main five teenagers and even Peter Stormare in this. They do show plenty of emotion. Especially fright when it comes to the dangers that head their way. However, the writing is poor for everyone. Everyone is one-dimentional. There isn't much character development for them. Even I didn't care much for them, especially the one couple, which I swear one of them was gonna throw the other to the wolves. The story itself is kind of a mess. Remember in one of my previous reviews that I don't mind much of a video game/book adapted into a movie not all 1:1 as long as it's written well? Not so much in this film. At the start, we get the sense of seeing the finding Ella Rubin's character's sister and they found themselves into this housing area where it's the beginning of their endless loop of dying and coming back to life to start over. The mystery section is interesting until the twist on why that was the case that kind of ruined it. I will say there is a scene that was kind of interesting as this one scene had me think that they'd rushed the nights until someone pulled out a phone to see what was recorded. I'm not gonna lie, I like that loophole of a twist within that scene. I give this film credit for being its own thing coming from David S. Sandberg. I'd played the game once, before you ask. Despite the negative, I still had a fun time with it. I'm not shocked that folks don't like this film. I might be surprised that some love this film. Even to say, this could be in others' category on their list of so bad, it's good or so bad, it's bad. To me, I kinda put this on my list of so bad, I had fun with it. I just don't see myself watching this again in the future unless I'm bored. I'm not saying you should go out and see this and maybe wait until it hits the streaming service or rent it. But if you want to check it out for the theater experience, go right ahead. I'm giving this film five Clover with a smile on her face and pitch-black eyes, possessed out of ten. 5/10.

Ever heard of the pesky butterfly effect? Gamers who loved 2015’s “Until Dawn” will recall that split-second decisions could have huge, rippling consequences on who survives a terrifying night on Blackwood Mountain. This film adaptation, from the director of “Shazam!” compacts that already-cinematic experience into a spine-chilling and unpredictable movie, set in Glore Valley. The cool part is, even those who’ve played the game can’t say whether Cimino’s character Max lives or dies: they’ll have to buy a ticket and find out which way the deadly butterfly has gone. At the end of the day, the game is a 10-hour long movie, so the challenge was trying to condense that down into a two hour movie. Swedish Director David F. Sandberg (“Lights Out”, “Annabelle: Creation”) lives on the autism spectrum and is no stranger to horror movies so he stayed in his lane with “Until Dawn” a genuinely creepy, freak show and made the edit possible! Watch out for: Dr Hill who sums up the on screen action, “Trauma becomes terror and sparks ignite! and lookout for the Wendigos….a Native American legend of cannibalistic monsters. “Until Dawn” is set in a town that subsided during a mining disaster decades ago, the sets are impressive and intricate. I’m a sucker for this kind of folk lore connection in horror movies (“The Gorge”). Being an old coal and limestone mining town Ipswich, Queensland, Australia people can relate to both mining disasters and subsidence. The happy Hollywood ending didn’t sit well with myself or other people at my screening. It felt like the producers of “Until Dawn” just wanted to keep their test audiences pleased. Stay for the closing credits on the Missing Persons Wall for photos of all the cast and crew. The closing scene hints at a sequel at the same location, but in winter which is more in keeping with the original video game. Still “Until Dawn” is a solid horror flick and way better than “Sinners” in this department. “Until Dawn” takes place on the same night, but it will leave you with different nightmares! Have you got what it takes to survive “Until Dawn”?

10 years since the successful popular video game made its debut on the PlayStation 4 Horror director David S. Sandberg brings the title to life with a new gimmick It’s a scary version of ‘Groundhog Day’ involving more blood A young woman Clover and her 4 friends go searching for her missing sister Melanie after a family tragedy A gas station attendant directs them to an empty lodge in the woods Unbeknownst to Clover and her friends the horror begins when each of them dies and miraculously come back to life when the night resets itself putting them through a new scenario each time, slowly they realize they’ll keep dying unless they can survive until sunrise But how can they break the chain when they face such terrors as a killer in a mask, an old woman subduing her victims with an oxygen tank, spontaneous combustion or creatures known as Wendigos? I’ll be honest saying I was a bit nervous walking into this one since the fanbase treasures the game so much Of course several changes are expected to happen when you do an adaptation It was a very effective horror movie I gotta say, an entertaining one I got a lot of jolts and enjoyed the gore next to the kills What worried most was the time travel element but they make it fun with the looping from one crazy life or death situation to the next There’s also a ton of exposition at the beginning but they get that out of the way fast Plus there’s a very funny scene in the middle I appreciated that breaks the tension I’m very glad they brought in Peter Stormare, he was a big part of the game and without spoiling too much he wasn’t just a minor cameo in this Sandberg and the filmmakers still stick in minor elements from the original source material like references as well as Easter eggs fans will be able to spot They also do some nice world building as well I only knew one actress Odessa A’zion out of these unknowns; hardly any of them are likable minus the lead herself who’s trying to let go getting past her trauma It’s also a nice touch they break down each scenario as a physical manifestation of a person’s insecurities in a way, fear becomes trauma, our true horrors become what keeps us down, sticking together is how we get through messed up things, what’s more terrifying is not knowing what to expect next, what’s worse is surviving but living without those closest to you This truly felt immersive like you were part of the experience these victims go through The game itself already has a cinematic feel to it like an extended cutscene you can play with your controller so it’s a good thing here they decided to do something different and not be a shot-for-shot recreation After all like a video game if you’re main character dies you have to option to restart and try again so it does have that trait about it Im glad this is a decent adaptation that acts as a love letter to the horror genre that embraces its own nature as far as frights as well as time travel itself

After venturing into the universe of superheroes with the films Shazam! and Shazam! Fury of the Gods, director David F. Sandberg returns to horror in Until Dawn, a work sold as an adaptation of the popular game by Supermassive Games. With the promise of honoring the game's atmosphere and still flirting with the narrative structure of night survival, Sandberg delivers a film that has both hits and misses, in an unstable balance between creativity and narrative exhaustion. From the outset, Until Dawn seems comfortable abandoning the idea of a faithful adaptation. Although it uses the name of the game and makes some direct references to The Dark Pictures Anthology franchise, the film takes its own path, establishing an original story where each night the characters face a new deadly danger - from serial killers to supernatural curses and explosive infections. The concept, at first, is ingenious and provides a good deal of entertainment by exploring the different types of threats that lurk around dawn. Each new challenge comes with the promise of heightening tension and creativity, and it's undeniable that on the first few nights this strategy works, supported by good practical effects and a constant sense of urgency. However, the same creativity that drives the plot also becomes its main Achilles heel. As the movie progresses, the exhaustion of ideas becomes evident. What once seemed like a succession of innovative events gradually loses momentum, causing the script to resort to easy, generic solutions from the horror genre, until it leads to an inevitable change of tone for the action in the third act. This abrupt transition not only weakens the atmosphere of tension built up until then, but also highlights the script's difficulty in sustaining its own concept until the end. The climax, which should represent the culmination of the narrative, sounds rushed and anticlimactic, leaving the feeling that much has been promised and little actually delivered. The homages to the original game, such as the presence of familiar characters and some recreated moments, try to create a link of nostalgia with fans. However, these references are merely superficial, since the essence of the game - centered on choices and emotional consequences - is practically lost amid the rush of the script. If it weren't for the title and a few winks to the original material, Until Dawn would work perfectly well as an independent horror movie, which reinforces the impression that the use of the brand was more of a marketing strategy than a legitimate artistic concern. On the emotional front, the story of Clover and Melanie, separated sisters in whom Clover is on a quest, is dealt with in a shallow manner. Although the film tries to insert internal conflicts related to guilt, redemption and loss, these themes are poorly developed and easily overshadowed by the creative death scenes and the frenetic pace of the narrative. The protagonist is even constructed with some care, but the depth of her personal dilemmas never becomes a driving force in the plot. In the end, the viewer cares more about the anticipation of the next threats than the emotional fate of the characters. Even with its flaws, Until Dawn has undeniable qualities within what it sets out to do: Sandberg's direction, especially with regard to the use of practical effects and the handling of tension in the first few nights, reveals a solid mastery of the genre. The film unashamedly embraces the clichés of teen horror, knowing exactly what kind of experience it wants to provide. However, the lack of consistency in the script, the abandonment of emotional depth and the mischaracterization in relation to the original material are factors that compromise the work as an adaptation and as a complete narrative experience. All in all, Until Dawn is a horror that starts off with breath and thought-provoking ideas, but gives in to predictability and haste in the final stretch. It's a production that amuses and entertains, but is too far removed from what it promised to be, disappointing fans in particular who were hoping to relive the intense experience of the game. As an independent film, it entertains in its best moments; as an adaptation, it's a missed opportunity.

O filme consegue manter a essência do jogo de 2015 e além de juntar peças, e fazer com que isso possa ter uma sequência explicando os devidos acontecimentos, além de que tudo do filme pode ser uma grande revelação do jogo que ninguém esperava mudando todo o rumo, o diretor foi muito criativo com isso. Sem contar que o elenco é incrível, você se importa com os personagens e torce por eles, cenas de susto são bem feitas sem se exageradas, várias cenas tensas. As criaturas por serem muitas ficaram um pouco de lado, mas a primeira aparição de cada uma delas é sensacional. Posso dizer que é um dos melhores filmes de 2025, que venha until dawn 2 jogo e filme. Quem só viu o filme tem que ver o jogo para ter outra experiência, é simplesmente outro filme.

Tldr at the end. While the movie strays from the game quite a bit, my skepticism entering the theater was soon replaced with tangible amusement as the movie manager to completely capture the feeling of playing a decision- based horror game. You can see where a player would make a choice via pacing and dialogue beats, you can tell where choices would reward a player with an "this action will have consequences" and you can tell when the wrong decision was made. The movie also captures the player experience of trying to get the ending where everyone lives, and constantly having to retry. This, in addition to Easter eggs, teasers and references to the story of the game left me with an overall positive feeling at the end of the film. Criticisms of the film involve pacing issues, one- dimensional and script-bound character writing and acting (Dr.Hill excluded), and the use of elements from the game too directly but incorrectly. **SPOILERS here** The use of Dr.Hill was fun, but fails to connect that he wasn't a person during his characterization throughout the game, he was a subconscious psychological construct in Josh's mind, based on a normal shrink named Dr.Hill. Additionally, changing the origin of the game's primary monster antagonist so drastically and away from it's origins was an interesting but unsuccessful way to shoehorn them in. Tldr; The movie was fun overall and pays homage to an entire genre of gaming in a way no other movie has, despite pacing issues and a lack of regards for the source material.

One of the better films Ive seen in a while.

Instantly one of my favorite horror movies. It translated the game's choose your adventure mechanic perfectly. I loved that they didn't explain the world and left us to figure out and other little things (that may have been by accident), that shows respect for the audience inteligence. Like when Megan is missing they didn't instantly thought that she had survived and left them there, the first thing they thought was that she had been captured, they knew her heart. The theme of loyalty over fear perfectly displayed in an extreme and unreal circumstance without being cheesy was beautiful. Life can be scary but scarier is living it without friends, your chosen family.

Nothing too wrong with it really, it's not great but it's not bad. It is not trash, it has as much merit as any other film. I loved the game, and appreciate how this is another chapter in the game. Really, this could have been worse. I was genuinely scared a few times, and the lead acting and creature special effects were good. There's a lot of intentional humor, and I found the end kind of refreshing. Wonky pacing and extremely bad makeup were the only things that really distracted me.

Once again another video game adaptation bites the dust. Not only is it not like the game but it strays far from that and only leaving the Wendigos, but even the rules for that was changed. Even with what I said they still try to connect it to the game but there’s no need because they’ve now destroyed established lore. Having Dr. Hill come in for a tie in the game won’t change minds, but instead rolls eyes. Characters are extremely one dimensional and there is no worry for these characters as you know they’ll just come back. The only thing I’ll give it is the practical effects, gore, and bloody kills. Even that’s not saying much as I always say those stuff are the icing on the cakes or the cherries on top. The main course should be the story and characters. Overall if it ain’t broke don’t fix it, and just like Godzilla 1998, this movie was Until Dawn in name only.
